Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Two-Dimensional Heterostructures Based On Transition Metal Dichalcogenides
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Description: Single layers of materials, also called 2-dimensional (2D) materials, are atomically thin materials that present an unusual combination of mechanical, optical and electronic properties; thus they are very attractive candidates for new-generation opto-electronic devices. Hetero-structures, i.e., stacking layers of different 2D materials, can be created to achieve new functionalities; by altering the local chemistry of a single layer, one can integrate different local properties in the hetero-structure. Although it is an essential step, the fabrication of such 2D hetero-structures still remains a technological challenge. The main goals of this project are to establish reliable methods and procedures to fabricate these complex 2D structures, and to acquire a clear understanding of the chemistry-structure-properties relationship by performing a comprehensive characterization of the heterostructures and related devices. The study is expected to impact future directions of 2D materials research through identifying and overcoming critical technical barriers, and facilitating the next generation, energy efficient, portable and flexible electronics. The project also includes genuine efforts oriented to raise the awareness of science among young students from underrepresented groups, and to motivate them for STEM disciplines. The research activities integrate with the educational plan, including involving undergraduate students early for research experiences, expanding the international collaborations with Mexico and Brazil, and increasing the participation of minority students in graduate studies.

Technical Description: This project aims to advance the fundamental knowledge on the physical properties of two-dimensional crystals, e.g., atomically thin transition metal dichalcogenides with a higher degree of complexity, and their heterostructures. Innovative synthesis approaches, including multistep masking and thermal evaporation/deposition by alternating sources, and, lithographic and laser writing techniques in controlled environments, are used to create uniform and reproducible arrays of two-dimensional hetero-structures, both in-plane and vertically stacked. State-of-the-art optical, structural and electrical characterization techniques are applied to explore both the formation mechanisms of the hetero-junctions at the atomic level, and the effects of local chemistry and atomic arrangement on the overall physical properties of the heterostructures. In addition, the effects of doping and alloying on the optoelectronic properties, band gap tuning and electronic band alignment at the hetero-junctions, are also investigated. Furthermore, the project comprises the fabrication and testing of a variety of new optoelectronic devices such as photo-sensors, photovoltaics and light-emitting sources that use the two-dimensional hetero-structures as the active elements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

This project aimed to advance the fundamental knowledge on the physical properties of two-dimensional crystals, focusing on atomically thin transition metal dichalcogenides with a higher degree of complexity, and their heterostructures. This study produced the following major intellectual contributions:

i)          Our group made a groundbreaking discovery by developing, for the first time, a one-pot synthesis approach using a single heterogeneous solid source for the continuous fabrication of lateral multi-junction heterostructures of TMD monolayers. The new approach offered a level of flexibility and control never achieved before in continuous growth of TMD-based multi-junction lateral heterostructures. The method is universally applicable to both selenides and sulfides, as well as ternary alloys. Additionally, it allowed to produce bilayer heterojunctions with the same level of control which also represented a breakthrough in the field. The study revealed the physical behavior of these heterostructures as well as the growth mechanisms involved in its formation. These results were published in highly reputed journals such as Nature and ACS Nano. The findings were highlighted by different online news outlets. 

ii)        We also developed an innovative approach for on-demand laser-assisted chemical modification of two-dimensional materials within reactive environment. This allowed to monitor, for the first time, the evolution of the Raman and PL spectrum in real time while the laser-induced reaction is taking place. With this setup laser-assisted replacement of chalcogen atoms in semiconductor TMDs facilitated the creation of heterogeneous 2D materials. Additionally, we also explored local doping of TMDs assisted by photo-chemical reaction. Our findings pave the road for developing laser writing techniques and on-demand creation of monolithic 2D circuitry.

The results of this project were disseminated to the scientific community through 9 publications in peer reviewed journals, 14 conference presentations and 11 invited talks.

 Broader Impact:

The findings in this project shone light on fundamental questions about the mechanisms ruling the lateral epitaxial growth of 2D heterostructures and their physical behavior. But its impact goes beyond the field of 2D materials since innovative synthesis methods for producing 2D lateral heterostructures, with potential for scalability, could accelerate the development of 2D circuitry. The 2D heterostructures also revealed great potential as transistors, light emitting devices, photosensors and presented photovoltaic behavior. The possibility of tuning of the bandgap in ternary lateral heterostructures also expands the range of optoelectronic applications.

The project also offered opportunities for training, professional development for one post-doctoral fellow and two PhD students. Additionally, a total of 15 undergraduate students, including a high school teacher, acquired research experience in the PI's lab. Among them, nine were from underrepresented groups (six females and three Hispanic-Latino). Under the project's umbrella, high school students visited the PI's laboratory and participated in experimental demonstrations. The high school students were also exposed to the ideas and methods that are routine in higher education, introducing them to organized research with the aim of raising awareness and interest for STEM disciplines.
